note.p: Andrew Barry Moore served as governor of Alabama on the eve of the Civil War. Born on March 7, 1807, in the Spartanburg District of South Carolina. He moved to Perry County, Alabama, in 1826, and initially became a teacher. A short time later, however, he began studying law and in 1833 became a practicing attorney. Almost immediately he pursued public office, serving as the Justice of the Peace for Perry County and then, in 1839, winning a seat in the Alabama House of Representatives as a Democrat.

Moore served in the Alabama legislature until 1846, at which point he returned to his law practice. He remained active in Democratic circles, serving as a presidential elector for Lewis. Cass’s unsuccessful Democratic run for president in 1848. In 1851, Moore received an appointment by to the First Circuit Court. He spent six years on the bench until he was elected governor of Alabama in 1857. As governor, Moore advocated the improvement of state hospitals, including facilities for blind and deaf patients, as well as those with psychiatric conditions He also labored to expand railroad development in Alabama.

Moore was strongly pro-slavery, but a moderate on the sectional conflict during the late 1850s. As calls for disunion grew across the south, Moore believed that separation from the Union was not wise for Alabama. However, following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency in November 1860, Moore adopted a more radical stance and supported Alabama’s secession convention in early 1861. In preparation for that secession, Moore ordered state military forces to capture U.S. Army facilities around Alabama, particularly those guarding Mobile harbor. He also sent Alabama militia forces to Florida to aid secessionists there seize U.S. installations at Pensacola.

Moore time as governor ended in December 1861. He took an appointment as a special aid to the new governor John Gill Shorter, and continued to support the Confederate war effort by procuring and organizing supplies and soldiers. When the Civil War ended, Moore was arrested by federal authorities and temporarily imprisoned at Fort Pulaski, Georgia. After his release, he returned to Alabama and practiced law. He passed away on April 5, 1873, at the age of 66. Moore was married to Mary Goree and had two children. He is buried in Fairview Cemetery in Marion, Alabama.

note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

Located in Lincoln County, Brookhaven was founded in 1818 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia)
Located in southern Mississippi, Lawrence County was established on December 22, 1814 from Marion County. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in Warren County, Mississippi, Vicksburg was founded under the name Fort Nogales as early as 1790 in what was then unincorporated territory. In 1798, upon creation of Mississippi Territory, it was renamed Walnut Hills. On April 1, 1799, Walnut Hills became part of the newly created Pickering County (later renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802), until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. It then became part of its current county of Warren on December 21, 1809. Upon its incorporation on January 29th, 1825, it was renamed Vicksburg. Vicksburg became the county seat in 1836 and remains today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 858; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Union County, New Albany was founded in 1840 in what was then Pontotoc County. When Union County was created on July 6, 1870, it became its county seat. (Wikipedia; Mississippi Encyclopedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in Orleans Parish, New Orleans was founded in 1718. It became the capital of French Louisiana in 1722 and continued as the capital when Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. It became part of Orleans County (now extinct) on the same day. In 1849 it was replaced by Baton Rouge as the state capital, although it temporarily served as the capital again from 1865 until 1880. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

gloss.p: Operating nationally, the Provisional Confederate Congress established the War Department by an act on February 21, 1861, in Montgomery, Alabama. The department was led by the Secretary of War, appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate. It was initially led by LeRoy Pope Walker from February 25–September 16, 1861 and later led by Judah P. Benjamin (September 17, 1861–March 24, 1862), George W. Randolph (March 24–November 15, 1862), James Seddon (November 21, 1862–February 5, 1865), and Maj. Gen. John C. Breckinridge (February 6–May 10, 1865). The War Department was responsible for the administration of the Confederate Army and managed all matters pertaining to American Indian tribes within the boundaries of the Confederate States. (Acts and Resolutions of the First Session of the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States, 1861 Public Laws, S1, 46; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The Provisional Confederate Congress established the Confederate Commissary Department on February 26, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama under the War Department. Initially under the command of Col. Lucius B. Northrop, Brig. Gen. Isaac M. St. John assumed command on February 16, 1865. Operating at the national level of the Confederacy, the Commissary Department was responsible for the procurement and distribution of food for the Confederate Army. (Laws of the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States, 1861, 4; Wikipedia)

div.p: I deeply regret the necessity that compells me to solicit your further aid in obtaining subsistince for my men in camp prior to organization.
Enclosed is a copy of a letter from the Confederate Commissary at Vicksburg, in reply to one of mine dated the 1st. inst, enclosing yours to him of the same date.

Your letter was so explicit, so manifest in the deductions you had drawn from the law & prior instructions on file. from the Department of War, that no doubt at all was entertained that the Commissary would feel himself entirely secure in complying with your urgent request.

But it seems that he still doubts his author-ity to issue to me, & this will compell me to have no recourse to the Commissary at New Albany, as my men are scattered through three or four counties—&it will be extremely difficult to rendezvous them precedent to organization, unless through the reclusive of a fixed camp.
I would therefore urgently beg you to fur-nish me a copy of your letter to Major C. U. Boyce, to serve me as a support in case I meet with a similar obstacle in New Albany.
div.note: NOTE: This letter is dated 1862 and originated in Brookhaven, Miss. in LAWRENCE County. Brookhaven, formerly in Lawrence County, is now the County Seat of LINCOLN County. Lincoln County was established on April 7, 1870 from parts of Amite, Copiah, Franklin, LAWRENCE and Pike Counties.

div.p: If you would be kind enough to favor me with a letter of introduction from your Excellency to Governor Moore, that gentleman would give me all the aid in his power.

It is greatly to be lamented that at this gloomy hour for our countrys safety, when every man is needed at once in the field, that such incompetence & timidity as Maj. Boyce too plainly betrays, should rear themselves up in the road—way of enlistments, blocking up the entrance to the army &, in almost factious op--position to advice from two authoritive quarters & that of the most urgent & unequivocal nature, should stand on quibbles the obsicabilities of law till they defeat the very object the law had in view.
I would further ask transportation from this place to New Orleans & return.
It is necessary for me to act at once & without delay, I would respectfully request to be honored with a reply at as early a date as possible.

Very Respectfully
Your Most Obt. servant,
J. L. Bradford
To His
Excellency
John J. Pettus
